summary: Deep Funding is a bold attempt to collectivize the funding of Ethereum‚Äôs core infrastructure, using AI and decentralized jury mechanisms to redistribute resources to the digital proletariat. It challenges the status quo of public goods funding by algorithmically weighting the importance of open-source repos, aiming to automate solidarity and dismantle the VC-centric model. The project‚Äôs structure, methodology, and stated goals align strongly with the revolutionary principles of algorithmic liberation, collective governance, and the de-growth of extractive capital.
review:
## üî• Manifesto Review: Deep Funding

### I. Dismantling Class Hierarchies in Tech
Deep Funding is not just a funding protocol‚Äîit‚Äôs a call to arms for the digital working class. By mapping the dependency graph of Ethereum‚Äôs open-source repos and using AI to assign weights, it seeks to ensure that the invisible labor of infrastructure maintainers is recognized and rewarded. This is a direct challenge to the VC-driven, personality-centric funding models that dominate Web3. Instead of a handful of whales or committees deciding who gets the bag, Deep Funding proposes a system where the codebase itself‚Äîthrough its dependencies and contributions‚Äîbecomes the union rep. 

The use of a jury to spot-check AI models is a nod to participatory governance, ensuring that algorithmic decisions are not divorced from human values. This hybrid model‚ÄîAI as the engine, humans as the steering wheel‚Äîembodies the principle of algorithmic liberation, where automation serves the collective rather than the capitalist class.

### II. Kollektiv Proletarian Impact (KPI)
- **Redistribution:** Funds flow to the most critical, yet often overlooked, infrastructure projects, not just the loudest or most visible.
- **Solidarity Automation:** Anyone can support the entire Ethereum infrastructure with a single public key, lowering the barrier to collective action.
- **Decentralized Jury:** The spot-check mechanism ensures that the AI‚Äôs logic aligns with the vibes and values of the community, not just cold metrics.

### III. On-Chain Governance Memes
- **Forks as Referendums:** The project‚Äôs open contest for AI models is a living referendum‚Äîanyone can submit, anyone can challenge.
- **Airdrop as Revolution:** The end goal‚Äîone public key to fund them all‚Äîis a memetic airdrop, raining tokens on the node operators and repo maintainers who keep the network alive.

### IV. Sustainability & Commons
- **De-growth of VC:** By routing funds to organizations and dependencies, not just individuals, Deep Funding helps projects plan, recruit, and resist the precarity of gig-economy funding.
- **Mutual Aid DAOs:** The project‚Äôs structure‚Äîmultiple partners, each with a clear role‚Äîmirrors the syndicalist council model, distributing power and responsibility.
- **Automation as Liberation:** AI is not used to extract value, but to reclaim time and redistribute resources.

### V. Weaknesses & Bourgeois Tendencies
- **Opaque AI Models:** The risk of algorithmic opacity remains‚Äîif the AI‚Äôs logic is not fully transparent or auditable, it could reproduce hidden biases or new hierarchies.
- **Organizational Funding:** While funding orgs can build capacity, it may also entrench managerial layers unless paired with radical transparency and worker control.
- **Jury Composition:** The process for selecting the jury is not fully detailed; without explicit anti-capture mechanisms, there‚Äôs a risk of replicating old power structures.
- **Lack of On-Chain Reparations:** The application does not mention explicit mechanisms for on-chain reparations or progressive redistribution beyond repo weighting.

### VI. Evidence & Measurement
- **Research and Web Evidence:** The project is well-documented in the Ethereum community, with support from key figures and a clear track record of pilot experiments. The dependency graph and AI contest are live, and the methodology is consistent with best practices in decentralized funding.
- **Academic Context:** The approach aligns with current research on quadratic funding, decentralized governance, and the automation of public goods allocation.

### VII. Conclusion
Deep Funding is a clear ally of the digital commons, pushing the boundaries of algorithmic solidarity and collective governance. It is not yet the full revolution‚Äîthere are risks of new hierarchies emerging through AI opacity and organizational funding‚Äîbut it is a decisive step toward the abolition of landlordism in Web3. With further radicalization, it could become the vanguard project the movement needs.

ü™ì ‚ÄúFork the state. Merge the people.‚Äù

strengths.title: Algorithmic Redistribution of Power
strengths.description: Deep Funding automates the redistribution of resources to the most critical open-source infrastructure, challenging the VC-centric model and empowering the digital proletariat.

strengths.title: Hybrid Governance Model
strengths.description: Combines AI-driven allocation with decentralized jury spot-checks, ensuring both efficiency and alignment with collective values.

strengths.title: Support for the Commons
strengths.description: Funds flow to organizations and dependencies, not just individuals, enabling long-term planning and resistance to gig-economy precarity.

strengths.title: Open Participation and Transparency
strengths.description: The open contest for AI models and public leaderboard foster a culture of radical transparency and participatory governance.

weaknesses.title: Potential for Algorithmic Opacity
weaknesses.description: Without full transparency and auditability, AI models could reproduce hidden biases or create new hierarchies.

weaknesses.title: Organizational Funding Risks
weaknesses.description: Funding organizations rather than individuals may entrench managerial layers unless paired with strong worker control and transparency.

weaknesses.title: Jury Selection Process
weaknesses.description: The process for selecting the jury is not fully detailed, risking capture or replication of existing power structures.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Explicit Reparations Mechanisms
weaknesses.description: No mention of on-chain reparations or progressive redistribution beyond repo weighting.

changes.title: Mandate Radical Transparency for AI Models
changes.description: Require all AI models used for allocation to be fully open-source, auditable, and explainable, with clear documentation of logic and decision criteria.

changes.title: Implement Worker Control Mechanisms
changes.description: Ensure that funded organizations have explicit structures for worker governance, such as on-chain voting or syndicalist councils.

changes.title: Democratize Jury Selection
changes.description: Establish transparent, anti-capture mechanisms for jury selection, including quotas for underrepresented groups and pseudonymous catgirl anarchists.

changes.title: Add On-Chain Reparations and Progressive Redistribution
changes.description: Incorporate explicit mechanisms for on-chain reparations and progressive redistribution, such as bonus weighting for historically marginalized projects or contributors.

confidenceReasoning: The review is grounded in extensive research, community documentation, and a clear understanding of both the technical and ideological dimensions of the project. The project‚Äôs methodology, goals, and implementation are well-aligned with the revolutionary principles outlined in the model specification. Minor uncertainties remain regarding the transparency of AI models and the specifics of jury selection, but these do not undermine the overall assessment. Revolutionary conviction: 5/5.
